name: Greyfox RPG
description: You play as a new arrival to a foggy and mysterious town. You find yourself waking up in the bodies of the town's inhabitants at pivotal moments of their lives. Make tough choices as you discover the truth about this town called Greyfox.
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows XP, Vista, 7, 8 Processor: Intel Pentium III 800 MHz Memory: 512 MB RAM DirectX: Version 9.0 Storage: 250 MB available space

reviews.review_text: Greyfox is a modern RPG-game made via RPG-Maker VX Ace with an interesting storyline and unique gameplay.  Pros: +Interesting Storyline +Great Controls +Graphics and sounds suit the game +Cheap price +Has achievements  Cons: -Game is short -Can be Depressing  Overall Rating: 8/10 Good game, Worth the cost, playable for an hour or two.

1h42 minutes. That's how long it took me to finish that game 100%, get all the achievements, and looking into every nook and cranny to get all the dialogs. This is not a RPG, at all. This is an adventure game, a story, where you make decisions. Those decisions are pretty much limited to 4 binary choices, kill or don't kill. They don't change much of anything, just a comment in the epilogue.  The only thing here is the story and deciding the fate of the characters. There's pretty much no story, just looking at a slice of life of 4 elderly people at the end of their rope (and it's possibly all a dream anyway). The characters are uninteresting, shallow, and often unoriginal. There's a lot of pee and poop 'jokes' (not sure if they're supposed to be jokes), and nearly everyone is an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥.  I couldn't care less about the characters, and the only thing here is to decide what happens to them (which might not actually do anything anyway). That makes it really pointless.  And short. Which is probably a good thing, now that I think about it. Since it felt like a waste of time, it's better that way. It's not horrible, but it wasn't enjoyable or interesting or memorable to me.  Now I'm going to let it run a few hours to drop the cards and uninstal it forever. I supposed it's a cheap way to get trading card even if the game itself isn't all that good.

Take a look and enjoy hopefully but dont deserve to much, if you like stories games fine if not there are enough other games at steam. Thank you for reading.

Pros ~ +For 19 cents this game is definitely worth it,   HOWEVER,   this game is not really worth the base price of $4.99 in my opinion +Free roam for the most part; lots to discover +The graphics was more than expected +Storyline was well thought out and executed +Simple and easy controls for ease of gameplay +Music and sound is on point +Achievements and cards  Cons ~ - Relatively short - Storyline can be very dark at times depending on yourself and your decisions - Depending on how you look at it: Focus was not on the 'main' character's characterisation, more on the 4 old people you play through as  If you like games where you can browse at your leisure and choices that shape your destiny, this is a game for you. Having completed one playthrough of this game, I found it to be charming and fairly thought-provoking. It starts out fairly average, leaving the player to feel as if they are simply going about their character's normal life... which they are. Little will you know until later on how ironic the character's comment, 'I am taking control of my life' is, in consideration of what happens next.  It doesn't take long to finish the game, but the different outcomes you can get for different, vital choices in the game encourage more than one playthrough, at least if you're curious how fate can happen differently. Overall it's pretty straightfoward though, and you get to experience life through the eyes of different people and become responsible for their fate... literally.  My favorite thing about the game is that the antagonist isn't painted in black and white; she isn't necessarily evil, even if she denies responsibility for any of the tragedies that happened (even if she is a direct influence and she is responsible for placing you in a position where you can make potentially bad choices). However, it could be argued that she is simply trying to enhance your knowledge and your perception on life... even if her reasons for doing this are unclear.  Either way, it's definitely worth a playthrough or two. Especially if you're in a mildly sadistic mood.
If you could see the life of others through their own eyes, would you play God?

While going through my Que, a game in the JRPG Bundle was listed. I have a history with RPG Maker games, and checked out its page. I don't like seeing many of the harsh reviews people have because of poor writing or the way some people use their RPG Maker games as a sort of 'fan-fiction,' ripping off ideas from other media instead of being completely creative and fresh. That being said, I noticed that I could buy the one game for 49 cents on sale, or buy 4 games in this bundle for the same price. Honestly, who could complain about such a cheap game? So I bought it and the same day played the smallest game on the list, Greyfox RPG. First off, I couldn't call this a JRPG for anything, and I could barely call it an RPG in the sense I am familiar with RPGs. (Although, in the sense of you playing the role of a person, this IS an RPG.) It is just like the description says. You move to a town called Greyfox where you meet a mysterious woman and you get to live the lives of 4 old people in the town. You decide what happens at the end of their lives, and can possibly solve a mystery or two along the way. I have only played through once so far, getting the 'bad' ending, but I liked its premise. I played a Psychological-Horror type game with RPG Maker when I was a lot younger, and appreciated the use of the program for story-telling, rather than a traditional 'kill enemies and level-up' RPG game. There are a few little secrets to find, a little bit of humor, and many 'What exactly is going on here?' moments that make you feel like you're in the main character's shoes. So far, I can't say I would spend the full $1.99 on it, but if you ever come across another sale where the game is 49 cents or is in a bundle with other games dropping the price down to around 12 cents, pick it up. It's a fun little gem, perfect for playing on a night where you wake up at 2am and can't get back to sleep, or any time you have an hour to kill.

I picked this game up, while it was on sale for 0,19€, and I would certainly say that I got my money worth. I however wouldn't recommend that you buy this game at full price, as 4.99€ seem a bit extreme.  The game is a typical 2D RPG game, with very simple controls and the graphics are what you can expect from this kind of game. The game has a short storyline attached to it, which will take you about 1 hour to complete, if you dont rush your way through the game that is. I liked the game for what it is, and I would say the storyline was a bit different from other games I have played.  Oh and the game has different endings, depending on how you choose to play out the game ;)   For achievement hunters. It's a relatively easy game to get 100% in, as it took me about 2½ hours to do. It can however be done alot faster, because I didn't even start looking at the achievements untill I was done with my first playthrough, and I guess if you abuse the save options a bit, and plan ahead, it won't really take you long.

Bought on sale for 0,19 euro and it probably isn't worth more. It's depressing 1 hour game with 3 endings. Did everything in 3 hours. The RPG tag is highly questionable, since arent any quests, no partyrecruitment, no gear, no threat, no deapth. no nothing. You play as woman who's miserable and comes to a small town called Greyfox, where she comes into contact with a mysterious woman, resulting in her getting to experience 4 tragic elderly strangers lives and decide their fates....

The love and effort that went in to this game is entirely in the story and dialogue, but it's there. The game uses default assets from RPG Maker for the most part, which doesn't spoil things save the occasional piece of design that really feels out of place, but moreso just feels like a big a missed opportunity. Hopefully this little game does well. I'd definitely be interested in another one in the future that had it's own custom design work.   Still, the story, dialogue, and general vibe were interesting enough for me to keep playing for a bit. On sale, I'd definitely say it's worth the price of admission.

I enjoyed this short and simple game. There's always something charming about the pixel sprites, the familiar font and the SFX of RPG Maker games. You play as a character that gets to see different perspectives in a town resident's life and choose what happens in that storyline. If you like minor philosophical plots and don't mind a short pixel game of the RPG Maker variety, then buy it (I purchased it on sale). The acheivements are fairly easy to get, too.  One note that may help any forms of cynicism on the story: the Mysterious Lady can say some things about life that you disagree with, but think of her as just a character with an opinion and not the opinion of the creator (because who knows if it is or just a perspective considered). There's some humor here and there, too.

For a short casual game, it's not bad. It's a story-telling RPG, or a point-and-click adventure, not a combat RPG. The plot is interesting, with three endings based on your choices. The game is like a thought about old age, death, and consequences. If a person is spiteful, has a dull life, or did something horrible, does that person deserve death? Do we have the rights to judge and execute them? How about the guilt of killing a human regardless of his/her crime/life/way of treating people?, etc. Each person will have their own answers for these questions, and the endings are just the developer(s)'s point of view, so you may agree or disagree. Anyway, it's a nice game. But as I said before, it's short, about 1-2 hours, so personally I prefer to get it on sale.
